body:
Can you elaborate a bit?

We now support the following selection modes

* Cell-by-cell as cursor moves
* Semantic selection (i.e. words) on double-click *and* as cursor is moved after double-click.
* Line select on triple-click and as cursor is moved after triple-click

Is there something beyond that we should support?

In Termite once you press Ctrl+Shift+Space you enter selection mode. You move the cursor around using hjkl, enter visual mode (using v) to select text, scroll using Ctrl+B, Ctrl+F and so on. Pretty much just like Vim. It might be the same thing as cell-by-cell selection, I'll have to try. How do I test it?
Oh, we don't have anything like that. However, I have already been considering such a feature, so expect to see it added at some point in the future.

Changed the title to _Modal keyboard controls_. The feature is basically as described--enter "normal" mode with some hot key, v to enter "visual" mode, keybindings for scrolling, selection manipulation, etc.

issue.title: Support for vi-like mode(Insert, Selection)
issue.body:
For users those who prefer window managers(and command line) in general, tend to use their keyboard for all purposes. 

I like alacritty but I miss a feature from [termite](https://github.com/thestinger/termite) such as selection mode, which enables me to select text in the terminal with just the help of keyboard(just to mention, it is lot more efficient than using the mouse and selecting terminal output text!). 

Are there any plans on implementing such feature?

issue.title: No Wrap Mode
issue.body:
I frequently run commands that have outputs which wrap text onto newlines (as we all do), the way we handle this today is the correct default behavior, but it would be neat to have the ability to active a "no wrap mode" where the arrow keys (h,j,k,l too) would scroll around the text. This would remove a very common pattern of rerunning the last command piped to `less -S`.

I understand this project is resistant to new features (for good reason), so I won't be offended if this is closed in the name of complexity. I do think this would be a relatively small complexity add if we are already thinking of adding modes as in #262, and #1017.

body: Now that we have scrollback, if this feature was added, it would be a killer feature for alacritty. Although I'm wondering if it's something that could be abstracted away and implemented on a higher level if alacritty was extracted into a library or if this needs to be baked in. I'm not a terminal dev, just an avid fan, so that's where my knowledge ends.

issue.title: URL recognition
issue.body: Other popular linux terminals often have a feature when you mouse over a URL it highlights and you can right click to open them in a browser.  I believe this is often referred to as "dingus click".  I find it a very handy feature.

issue.title: opening links using keyboard
issue.body:
Which operating system does the issue occur on?
Linux

If on linux, are you using X11 or Wayland?
X11

Hello, thanks everyone for this fine terminal already. I was just wondering if there's ever going to be a feature where it'll be possible to select&open weblinks using keyboard only. For example in Termite it's possible to use Ctrl+Shift+X to select a link using a number, which will then be opened.
Feel free to burn me down as well :P I just thought it'd be useful, mainly for the rather selfish reason that I use it a lot, and am a beginner at coding.

issue.title: how to select line with cursor keys?
issue.body:
Which operating system does the issue occur on?

Windows

If on linux, are you using X11 or Wayland?

NA

Not using the mouse at all, is it possible to select and copy the current line using **only** cursor keys?

issue.title: URL selection mode
issue.body:
Hi, I use Alacritty on Arch Linux. I am missing one feature from termite. In Termite you could open up an `URL selection mode` (CTRL+SHIFT+X). In this mode the terminal will pop up flags on URLs. This way you could press a button for a flag and you will open the URL magically in your browser. I know that I can click on the URL in alacritty, but this mode would be even more handy.
Here is a picture with it: ![https://paste.xinu.at/4qLMQ/](https://paste.xinu.at/4qLMQ/)

body:
Hi @jwilm @chrisduerr 
Alacritty is awesome and I use it every day both at home and work!

Just curious - is this feature on a roadmap? 
I use i3wm and currently if I want to scroll-back and copy something using keyboard i have to use tmux. This is not super convenient as tmux as I either need to start tmux manually for individual terminal instance or do automatic tmux enter on shell login. The latter creates a mess of a nested tmux layouts inside i3 layouts...

And are there any workaround? Are there users with i3 and what do they use for scroll-select-copy?

It's definitely planned, though since this is a pretty 'advanced' feature I can't make any guarantees that it will land anytime soon.

I'm interested in this myself, however I also want this done right and there are other features which might have priority for now.

issue.title: Feature Request: Hints for Regex
issue.body:
Hi,
I stumbled upon tmux-fingers. A really nice tmux plugin, that has a hint flag feature for several types of regexes. I thought about this a lot and I think it would be really cool if such features would be inside of alacritty: https://github.com/Morantron/tmux-fingers

What I would like to have is:
I type [ctrl]+[shift]+[space] [x] and i get hints for:

File paths
git SHAs
numbers ( 4+ digits )
hex numbers
IP addresses
kubernetes resources
UUIDs
URLs

then I can type a flag number in the terminal and i will copy the matched string

issue.title: Scrollback Buffer Search
issue.body:
Once we have scrollback (#124), it's pretty reasonable to want to be able to search that. The challenge here is building something that works well, while still feeling simple, clean and lightweight. This is I believe the first "mode" proposed to alacritty. As in I hit some key binding and suddenly the rules for what my keys do has changed. I can't think of any other modes right now, but maybe that helps inspire the design.

Anyway sorry for getting ahead of things here, but this is a feature I'm dying to have. For now re-running the command and passing it to `rg` will have to suffice.

body:
>  I'm wondering if it's something that could be abstracted away

Urxvt has this functionality implemented as a plugin https://github.com/muennich/urxvt-perls/blob/master/keyboard-select which suggests, I guess, that the answer is yes?

I also want to add as an urxvt user (on the edge of switching) that this feature is very much desirable.

I was just considering filing a similar issue, glad I searched first :)

I am interested in taking this issue on, although I understand @chrisduerr that you expressed some anxiety about doing it right so a relatively green Rustacean like myself might not be the most suitable person. I'd be happy to work on it with your direction though!

issue.title: select current line using keyboard without TMUX?
issue.body:
Which operating system does the issue occur on?

windows

If on linux, are you using X11 or Wayland?

Is it possible to use a keyboard combination like shift+Left/Right to select the text on the current input line without using TMUX?

issue.title: history to a file
issue.body: I would really appreciate (if this isnt supported already) to have some keybind that would output entire history of current alacritty instance to a file. I m using my setup with keyboard exclusively, I rarely touch a mouse for hours and this one thing is missing and forces me to use mouse, and that is ability to capture output of one of commands to my clipboard....I can easily imagine scripting it (and I have many more ideas) but i need to get that output somehow...I was thinking about using tmux for this but I would guess this should be trivial to implement. Please if this sounds like good idea, please let me know
